review:
Overall great game for it being super early access.  There isn't much to do, yet, but I like getting to the point where I'm bringing in more cash than I can spend (about 15-30 mins of gameplay) and trying to design cool space stations.  Just need more modules to add, currently there are a few locked.  

This game isn't for someone looking for a lot of action.  I find it to be more of a relaxation game.  When I'm stressed I get on and build a space station and zone out for about an hour.  

Pros: 
+ Graphics
+ Relaxing
+ Replay value is there (Building new stations)
+ Very few bugs
+ Updates seem to be on schedule

Cons:
- Needs more modules
- Camera movement (Have to click and drag mouse.  Would prefer to be able to use W,A,S,D as well)
- Would like to be able to save built stations edit: this feature is present with arrow selection on the right hand side of the main menu.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117387808', 'num_games_owned': 30, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 700, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 281, 'last_played': 1507571207}
review:
I like the game so far, it does have potential. I would recommend making the game a lot more realistic, starting with the time. Maybe keep it 1:1? With its current update, it doesn't take more than a couple of hours to "get comfortable". Once you realize all you have to do manage is power, heat, and consumables, it's just a matter of making additions to your space station. After the game starts getting closer to the more realistic side of things through updates, there just needs to be more module additions, and maybe some kind of story line with goals to achieve. 

As is, it's a great foundation to continue further development. With the next update release, Perihelion, scheduled to be released in late April, I am genuinely excited for what the developer has to bring to the table for all the early adopters. I can see this game right along KSP in the foreseeable future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043797507', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 389, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1621597232}
review:
I don't know what to think of this game. It is nice to look at. The music is relaxing (until you get you hear the vocal track). The idea of building my own space station is interesting. It was interesting enough to make me buy it while it is still Early Access. Something I swore that I would never do again.
I've only a hour play time before this review, and there probably won't be much more. Not in its current state. There doen't seem to be a point to the game. 
Build enough core items (water tank, oxygen generator/tanks, power source, etc) to keep a person alive. Build a science module to give said person something to do, and to earn money. Use said money to build the same, and additional living quarters, for more people to arrive at your station. Repeat. Repeat.
There is some forethought needed in planning your station. Although I'm not sure how much. Does the science module in front of the solar array actually effect the amount of power generated? 

Give me a challenge. Some random events. Something that makes my crew come down with Space Madness. Make the powers on Earth demand that a indepth study of Pigs in Space, and all the resulting puns, is required to ensure the funding continues. And let me be able to delete messages. 

I understand what Early Access is. I understand the game is intented to evolve and grow. I understand that this may never become the game I want.

Can I recommend the game as it stands now? 
I am hesitant to do so. If you want any kind of challenge it isn't for you. Not yet.

Would I recommend the game, if the developer actually completes everything on the development roadmap? 
Yes. Without hesitation.

I guess it comes down to the fundemental flaw with early access. Do you trust a developer enough to pass over your money? You already know my answer to that question.

author: {'steamid': '76561198038570177', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 346, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 346, 'last_played': 1487051121}
review:
Stable Orbit - 

TL;DR - Visually pretty, bug free, somewhat playable (Early Access), space station building sim (external view only).  
If you love space sims, I'd say go for it.   If you're not a space junky, then you might save your cash for when it's further along.

Even with the limited complexity of the Early Access state, it took me two stations to max out the game's current potential, which consists of balancing basic crew needs (literally haveing a powered habitat module), very simple thermal control, then power, water and O2.  WIth the generic "lab module" in place, crewmen can "work" and make $ which allows the purchase of necessary staiton bits.

The thrill ends when you have a few labs running 24/7, with crew assigned to all three shifts... and you've managed to purchase everything there is to be bought.

It took me about an hour to get there, but it was a fun hour.

Looking forward to the coming releases and of course 1.0.

I HOPE that this game will allow one to go INSIDE the station at some point.  That would be fantatsic...  maybe Vive and Oculus support?

review:
Updated Review:
With the Perihelion update the game gets sufficient content for the average punter to consider supporting a game in a favoured genrre. It's still not yet 'engaging' but it is certainly progressing along nicely and, based on current progress, should arrive at a fun little niche game. In it's current state expect maybe 4-5 hrs gameplay if you teach yourself, maybe 2-3 hrs if you read the guides. Afer that it begins to tail off and really only allows gameplay to continue just playing with the sandbox. Whilst I like the game, and have enjoyed playing, I think it still needs some sort of gameplay mechanic to really make it engaging. The orbit/disaster patch coming out in a few months may well achieve it. Looking forward to it.

Original Review:
[quote]Fun concept - see how the development goes. Right now very little immediate return (maybe 1-2 hrs) for money investment but if you like space games and have a bit of faith it looks like it has potential.

However, I can't really recommend this to people at this stage. It is extremely early access at this point. I'd give it 3-6 months and there is probably enough of a game to justify the cost.[/quote]

author: {'steamid': '76561198054818376', 'num_games_owned': 393, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 107, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1486415586}
review:
Stable Orbit is a really unique and interesting experience. The short time I played this game, I was amazed by the setting and often caught myself glazing at the Earth beneath the Space Station instead of actually playing the game.

However, this game is still deep in Early Access and after about one hour of play time it's extremely obvious why. Once the station is in a stable condition with enough resource containers, solar panels and radiators, there is nothing else to do than build more of the stuff that is already there.

But that currently the only negative thing I have to say about Stable Orbit, since the Developer Roadmap looks pretty ambitious and I am sure that the additional features (like thrusters to maintain the orbit or additional modules) will help the game become better and more long time motivating.

An additional feature I would like to see are Building Missions that provide a target to build a certain amount of a certain module (e.g. "The European Space Travel Agency demands the presence of at least to middle sized laboratories on the station"). Reaching this goal within a certain amount of time could be rewarded with additional funds.

Conclusion: A very promising game. Still lacking of content but on a very good way to become an insider.

review:
Sorry Stable Orbit, but when it takes me less than 15 minutes to master your game mechanics and you fail to offer anything more challenging than: Build more stuff! then I have to say: Money back, please.

A more extensive review:

You start with a small module in space. You add on a lab to make you money, solar panels for energy, habitats so your astronauts can sleep and heat vents to vent heat to space. 

At first, it is tricky to balance it. But you figure it out. Once that's done you've won the game! (Unless you enjoy just continually building the same combination of modules over and over again while you earn billions of useless money)

If you added in challenges, like random damage, debris strikes, astronaut freak outs.... any random event it might be a game. But as it stands it's little more than a Space Station Building Simulator (Think walking simulator style).

I don't give scores because you can't boil games down to a number.

THE END.

author: {'steamid': '76561198003124821', 'num_games_owned': 3021, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1478706848}
review:
This is a YES IF, NO BUT recommendation - This game is currently in VERY EARLY development.

[b]Flares, Big Hair and Disco[/b]

Those are the three words that sum up the 70's for me, but there's a lot more to the polyester decade than Boney M. and the Bee Gees.
Whilst the western world was listening to John Lennons "Imagine" and losing interest in the American Moon landings, the Soviets took their own giant leap for mankind with the launch of the first space station Salyut 1, this was the first step towards a permanent manned presence in space and a proof of concept for the following Salyut missions.
Back in the west there was a very different but just as significant "first" taking place in the form of the commercial release of something called "Pong".


[b]Smell the Future[/b]

Pong was of course the table tennis inspired arcade machine which managed to introduce "gaming" to the masses and make a buck or two for Atari in the process.

Pongs popularity was such that it led Atari to release "Home Pong" (not something you get when you break wind in your living room but rather a home games console which allowed fans to enjoy virtual ping-pong without leaving the house.)
This was the start of a revolution in home entertainment.
The humble paddle and ball game (well, stick and square game) paved the way to the mainstream world of gaming we all find ourselves living in today, a world where anything can be simulated, from table tennis to truck driving, space invaders to space stations, everything is fair game.

Which is great for us, we're living in a golden age of virtual entertainment, since Pongs release in the 70's the games industry has gone from strength to strength, but can we say the same about our extraterrestrial endeavours?


[b]Stairway To Heaven[/b]

Remember that space station we spoke about? Salyut 1?
That was launched in the same year as Pongs release, but it wasn't quite so long lived, orbiting the Earth for just 6 months before it fell like a led zeppelin in to the upper atmosphere.

The death of Salyut 1 was followed by several other short lived stations before the construction of the more enduring Skylab and Mir platforms in the 70's and 80's (both of which have subsequently died a fiery death).
Of course we now have the International Space Station, with 4 giant solar arrays providing power to over a dozen pressurised modules, powerful batteries and sophisticated telemetry.

The ISS is a modern wonder and one of mankinds greatest contemporary achievements.


[b]The Long and Winding Road[/b]

So we have the disco decade to thank not only for a permanent manned presence in space but also for the greatest hobby in the world, gaming.
That's a significant legacy and one which has culminated in the development of a game called Stable Orbit, a space station simulation title by Codalyn which gives you the chance to indulge in your gaming hobby and celebrate our space based ingenuity at the same time.
The first thing you should know is that at the time of writing Stable Orbit is in Early Access (and paradoxically not that stable) so you can expect a lot of missing features, a few bugs and the occasional crash, you can also expect some nausea but I'll get on to that later.


[b]Go Your Own Way[/b]

So Stable orbit gives you the opportunity to construct your very own space station.
As it stands at the moment, you start the game with a core module already orbiting the earth.
This provides a limited amount of power, cooling and communication capabilities.
There's also just enough life support to accommodate one brave astronaut.

From these humble beginnings you're tasked with constructing a station to surpass the ISS itself.
You're going to need a source of income to fund your construction ambitions, building a lab module is a good place to start as at the moment this is the only way to generate money (although this will likely change as development progresses).

You're going to need some extra power to keep things ticking over so putting up a solar array might be a good idea, maybe you could build  living quarters too, it'd be good for your solo astronaut to have a friend up there.
Of course you'll also need to construct a shuttle dock so your intrepid new astronaut can board the station, the dock is also important as it allows your station to receive vital supplies from Earth.

Your astronauts have developed an addiction to luxuries like food and water so it's a good idea to fit a "space door" to accept the online grocery orders, after all a dead astronaut isn't great for productivity.


[b]Seasons in the Sun[/b]

The next problem you've got is that whilst the solar panels are providing electricity to keep the lights on, they only work in sunlight, which isn't much use when you're on the dark side of the Earth and actually need to "turn the lights on" so it might be wise to attach some batteries to help keep things powered when you're orbiting through the shadows.

So now you've got a lab making you money and a living quarters for well... living in, everything is powered and your astronauts are fed, watered and oxygenated but it's still far from an orbital paradise.

Your technological tin can will get pretty hot with all that machinery running and unfiltered sunlight blazing on to its surface, you're going to need to build a radiator or two to regulate the temperature before you cook your cosmonauts.


[b]Wuthering Heights[/b]

A few button clicks and a short while later you'll have a Station happily circling the Earth without the need for further input from yourself.

You can click on a module and order some repairs if anything has gotten damaged, you could expand further, build another lab, a larger solar array, a bigger living quarters etc.
Bigger is always better and you can definitely build an impressively large station by repeating basic module construction over and over but therein lies the problem of playing through an early access title like this.

The current lack of content means that things are going to get stale pretty quickly and once you've built a station or two there isn't much left to do apart from admire your handy work in all its glinting metallic glory.

Watching your station orbit around the earth is fun for a while and a game of "find your house from orbit" will entertain for a few minutes more but you'll soon get sick of that and as I mentioned early, you might also get sick in the physical sense too. 


[b]Killing Me Softly[/b]

Whilst this "space sickness" might add a little something to the immersion it's an additional level or realism I could definitely do without.
The nausea is caused by the rapidly rotating Earth constantly spinning like a crazed merry-go-round beneath your shiny new space station.

The game currently has 3 speed settings, Too Fast, Way Too Fast and Vomit Now.

From a design point of view there's no denying that you need the ability to fast forward time speeding up the construction of modules etc, but you should also be able to slow things down and catch your breath.

Taking a few minutes to enjoy looking at your creation is part of the fun with this sort of game but with your station hurtling around the world at what feels like light speed, taking in the view can be an eye watering experience.
Stable Orbit desperately needs a "real time" setting so we can enjoy the view without the need for a sick bag.


[b]Another Brick In The Wall[/b]

There's a game I haven't referred to so far and I'm certain that if you have an interest in this type of simulation it will have already crossed your mind.
The elephant in the room is of course... [snip]

For the rest of the review please head over to [url=www.review-well.com]www.review-well.com[/url]

author: {'steamid': '76561198302619901', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1476563951}
review:
This is a great start for sure. I did not experience motion sickness, and watching your station develop is certain very nice indeed.

I do hope there will be more features in future, obviously some items are locked, so I'm sure they will eventually be available. What would be great is a comfortable management section, so see at a glance if something is damaged, maybe assign repair crews, maybe instead of eject, allow modules to be moved etc. Maybe also an option to control what the scientists are studying , that ability to align the station with thrusters etc., just all the things that are do-able.

While I agree, there isn't that much to do, I enjoyed what I could do and I certainly will give future updates a try.

The graphics are nice, controls are OK for now, what is missing is some ambiance. Maybe music, maybe some radio chatter between the station and ground control, especially when shuttles come and go. This game has great potential, and as I don't need action or shooting things to enjoy a game, I hope it retains a certain level of simulation and concentrates on science and management!

Great start, I do not regret buying this, even at Early Access stage!

The controls are buggy so there may be more to it, but I'm simply not able to click on things and there are times when the mouse locks on and there is no way to reset it. While the manual is open, the game fails to start. Yes. You have to close the manual in order to run the game.

It is not currently worth the price being asked. I received this (I think for free) through GreenManGaming. 

I strongly suggest waiting for a more developed version.

11/11/16
The game had an update today, gave it a very brief look. I think I can see where the creator is trying to end up with the game. Once an introduction, better tooltips and mouse controls are added for new players I may give the game a qualified recommendation.

As it is now, hold on to your money.

Vector Update:
So Stable Orbit has had its second update to Vector.
We got new models and new cabins for connecting livable units and various bug fixes.
We also got new settings for older machines(Hurray!)
The game is now to me playable with solid machanics and can now run on my older pc with decent frames instead of the 20 i was getting.

While the game is still lacking in content it is really showing promise at this time and i hope the developer keeps supporting his product.

I can now give it a thumbs up as it is in a state of where i think the starting line should be for an early access game.

Good Job, Codalyn and keep up the good work.

====================================================================
Electrolysis Update:
Stable Orbit has seen the first update for the game and so far it is coming along nicely.
Added was:
Better management UI
Food, Water, and Oxygen Storage and management.
Oxygen extractors
Slow Orbit of earth down to a total of 90mins to do a full rotation.(fixed some motion sickness for me.)

Overall the game is going in a good direction for it.

Still i cannot recommend the game at this time due to preformance issues along with a lack of features but it still continues to impress and i hope for the continued support of the developer.

Buy this if you want to support the developer but if you are looking for a full feature game Stable Orbit isnt the game for you at the moment.

To the developer i say keep up the good work, you will get there and keep us informed as that is your best PR.

TheJallie

Original Review:
==============
Stable Orbit is a Space Sim about building a space station after the ISS has been decommissioned. Currently the game is in Very early access so Items are limited but it is in a playable state.

Pros:
Space Sim(need more of these)
Management
Very Mellow

Cons:
Can cause motion sickness for some people if you look at earth too long.
Not Very realistic as it doesnt pass over standard launch sites on earth.
Very little customization.
Lack of information boxes when selecting items to build (so not much you can know when trying to build)
Management bar at the bottom is lacking more detailed information
Lack of a moon
Station is hard to see when it is in the Dark(would make it so you can see the station just make it low light or that station sections light up as you hover over)
Lack of seeing a modern shuttle instead of a 1960s shuttle.
Lack of settings to adjust quality on stuff for older PCs not using a GTX980+

What i would like to see:
More Options in modules like a garden/bio, Science is nice, Observation, Water recylers, Air scrubbers.
Less wireframe options as it doesnt fit with most extensions to a station but would be ok with it if you have an upgrade option.
Hotkey to disable health options on all modules as seeing green health bars all the time is annoying.
Better movement as i cannot get to some modules as they do not center when i click on them.
Zoom feature.
Slower planet rotation(even if it breaks reality(Would solve the motion sickness and other issues with hardware requirements))


Summary:
Stable Orbit is a diffrent but similar game with alot of potentala and while its doing itself good and i dont see any crashes there is a lack of missions or goals to complete.
My Recommendation to the developer is to focus on the station at the moment and fix and impliment some changes and get some goals in place for people to work twords. Then focus on other things like earth and weather for additional effects. As station building is the goal you want to enable people to work on that and to make what they want.

At this time i cannot Give it a recommendation because a various lack of features but it is something i would keep an eye on.

For others if you want to just do some basic station building this game can do it.

TheJallie
